channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: More than 860 Russians were detained at the protests on Sunday, bringing the total number of arrests at antiwar demonstrations to more than 14,500, according to a human rights group that tracks arrests in Russia. https://t.co/vUmPrHYlcz
Former President Barack Obama said on Sunday that he tested positive for the coronavirus and has a scratchy throat but is otherwise fine. https://t.co/ayruN1qUBy

Greenpeace, the global nonprofit, said that 125,000 people protested nationwide in Germany, including 60,000 people in the capital, Berlin, and 10,000 people in Hamburg. https://t.co/u6UYNDUEEW https://t.co/FZHq1w9bN0
Two sleeping homeless men were shot by the same person early Saturday morning, the N.Y.P.D. said. “We need to find this person,” Mayor Eric Adams said of the assailant. https://t.co/5hODJbn2S2

A train carrying Ukrainians fleeing eastern Ukraine came under fire, killing a conductor and injuring another person, the country’s national railroad said in a statement on Sunday. https://t.co/Qet8jdNfyV

Naomi Osaka, who addressed the crowd on Saturday after her defeat, said that heckling hadn't bothered her before. “But, like, heckled here? I watched a video of Venus and Serena getting heckled here, and if you’ve never watched it, you should watch it." https://t.co/GjnQvaBG2J

The British government will provide £350 (about $450) a month to people who host Ukrainian refugees, part of an effort to encourage individuals, charities, community groups and businesses to take in those fleeing the war. https://t.co/QRqa4QuUsy

Jake Sullivan, the White House national security adviser, is scheduled to meet on Monday in Rome with a senior Chinese official, the White House said on Sunday. The two are expected to discuss the war in Ukraine, among other topics. https://t.co/gA9MrEGiiB
Brent Renaud, an award-winning American filmmaker and journalist, was killed on Sunday while reporting in Irpin, a Kyiv suburb, Ukrainian authorities said. https://t.co/4ckuHiZoxK

Russia’s war in Ukraine has finally led the British government to go after ultrawealthy Russians in London. But curbing the flood of corrupt money will require going after more than the big names. https://t.co/qNWndwgZx5

Roman Abramovich’s billions and his Kremlin connections got him favors and elite status in the West — buying London’s Chelsea soccer team, luxury homes, masterworks and more. Now, they've landed him on a sanctions list. https://t.co/pgv3XhzGHJ

Prominent conservative voices have mischaracterized remarks from U.S. officials to amplify baseless claims about Ukrainian bioweapons labs that Russian state media have promoted. The White House, Pentagon, and State Department have denied the claims. https://t.co/TDCABvC9Ol https://t.co/x4sUzQsSNs

A growing cadre of scientists, politicians and business leaders in the U.S. have been urging the country to stop changing the clocks altogether, and to pick one permanent time system. https://t.co/i5YN7yakYu
Breaking News: Russian missiles hit a military base in western Ukraine, according to local officials, in a major escalation near the Polish border. https://t.co/WGXAgURTeW

An 83-year-old Brooklyn woman convicted twice of killing women she lived with was charged with murder on Thursday, after investigators found a head in her apartment that, officials said, belonged to a body discovered in a shopping cart last week. https://t.co/LuQN8lsTmH
Breaking News: Two women were stabbed at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, the police said. Both were in stable condition. https://t.co/VptdG3PN25

About two dozen streets in Manhattan’s Chinatown have bilingual street signs designating their official Chinese names. In recent years, some have been removed or replaced with English-only signs.
https://t.co/YkzQ0TCO6e https://t.co/tvH9XStyuY

The Russian invasion of Ukraine has bonded America to Europe more tightly than at any time since the Cold War and deepened U.S. ties with Asian allies, while forcing a reassessment of rivals like China, Iran and Venezuela. https://t.co/OHsTvdVC4s

Ivan Fyodorov, an ethnic Russian and the 33-year-old mayor of Melitopol, Ukraine, was kidnapped Friday by Russian soldiers, Ukrainian officials said. Hundreds of residents went to the streets Saturday demanding that the mayor be freed. https://t.co/FPz9KcJtx4

Senior Lt. Vasyl Vyshyvanyi was killed by Russian forces on March 3, but heavy combat kept the military from evacuating his body. Six days later, he was buried in his home village outside Lviv. https://t.co/u225GmjsTa

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said on Saturday that an estimated 1,300 Ukrainian soldiers have been killed in the war. It is the first time the government has offered an estimate of the number of its own soldiers killed. https://t.co/jki7TScvCI
Some American consumers are channeling their outrage over Russia's aggression in Ukraine by boycotting ... products that aren't even Russian. https://t.co/q11QIyTamm

“Of course we cannot abandon the babies,” said one nanny, who is caring for babies born to Ukrainian surrogate mothers and being sheltered in a basement nursery in Kyiv. Her husband and two sons, all soldiers in Ukraine’s army, have urged her to evacuate. https://t.co/nmLt8tfibS https://t.co/xoXGfHrpqa

The latest arms package, which officials say includes Javelin antitank missiles and Stinger antiaircraft missiles, follows a $350 million arms package the Biden administration approved last month.
https://t.co/ZNmiNw6eAT https://t.co/eK68PY2gUS
Researchers are keeping an eye on a highly transmissible subvariant of Omicron known as BA.2. Here’s what we know so far about it. https://t.co/p8glgY6RM5

President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Russia on Saturday of waging “a war of annihilation” as cities and towns came under sustained bombardment.
Here are the latest developments in Ukraine: https://t.co/FOLE3b62VP

"I told myself, ‘Either I watch the war on Facebook and write in comments and cry, or I go and help.’” A growing number of Ukrainians in the U.S., many of whom have never fired a weapon, are joining the fight against Russia. https://t.co/XJesd4fZSC

Five West Point cadets were among six young men on spring break who overdosed this week on what was believed to be cocaine laced with fentanyl at a rental home in Wilton Manors, Florida, officials said Friday. https://t.co/4pjQGafgJT

Roman Abramovich’s billions and his Kremlin connections got him favors and elite status in the West — buying London’s Chelsea soccer team, luxury homes, masterworks and more. Now, they've landed him on a sanctions list. https://t.co/gCS7fq9BwJ

As part of a fourth wave of sanctions against Russia for its invasion of Ukraine, the European Union and the U.S. announced Friday that they would no longer allow any exports of luxury goods to Russia. https://t.co/HIBl0bTOEj

Ukraine’s drones — Turkish-made Bayraktar TB2 models that buzz along at about half the speed of a Cessna — are not only still flying, they also shoot guided missiles at Russian missile launchers, tanks and supply trains, according to Pentagon officials. https://t.co/3xHr24oKxI

Roman Abramovich’s billions and his Kremlin connections got him favors and elite status in the West — buying London’s Chelsea soccer team, luxury homes, masterworks and more. Now, they've landed him on a sanctions list. https://t.co/Rc1wpTroWF
Rusty Mae Moore, a transgender educator and activist who housed hundreds of transgender people in the 1990s and 2000s in her Brooklyn home, died on Feb. 23. She was 80. https://t.co/PHbe2o3zdh

U.S. officials are examining the ownership of a $700 million superyacht currently in a dry dock at an Italian town, and believe it could be associated with President Vladimir Putin of Russia, according to multiple people briefed on the information. https://t.co/bqL7hv1xDn
“I expected a write-up. I did not expect to get terminated. I cried the entire way home.” https://t.co/WNZeSeZFKq
Breaking News: A Texas court halted the state from investigating parents of transgender children for abuse, ruling that the policy was improperly adopted. https://t.co/Sqg8vmhGNA

Pixar has a reputation for films focused on and written by men. But its latest movie, "Turning Red," bucks that trend: an unabashedly female story directed by Domee Shi, the first woman in the studio's 36-year history to be in charge of a feature. https://t.co/1KFqqz4aql

Prominent conservative voices have mischaracterized remarks from U.S. officials to amplify baseless claims about Ukrainian bioweapons labs that Russian state media have promoted. The White House, Pentagon, and State Department have denied the claims. https://t.co/eeoGBdpPdI https://t.co/Y0vSWnh9Lq

The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, slammed Russia for using the Security Council to spread disinformation and legitimize its invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/u8RiWdMpFp https://t.co/fwgMQ9AbOS

Ukraine's vast array of historic buildings, priceless artworks and public squares are an integral part of the country's cultural identity. Amid the violence of war, many are being reduced to rubble. https://t.co/xA4w5pcS7c https://t.co/CVdIwFs3oZ

Vice President Kamala Harris said the inflated costs in the U.S. were worth paying to penalize Russia over its invasion of Ukraine: “There is a price to pay for democracy,” adding that it is important to “stand with your friends,” she said. https://t.co/iSH3EbWD2W https://t.co/m42wcLzWqB

Oxxxymiron, also known as Miron Fyodorov, one of Russia's most popular rappers, announced a series of anti-war charity concerts, which will happen outside Russia because of "total censorship." The shows' proceeds will help those fleeing Ukraine, he said. https://t.co/SDPhrqPRCn

Three Ukrainian soldiers killed in combat were buried in Lviv on Friday, as civilian and military casualties keep rising in the war against Russia. Elsewhere, the rumble of heavy artillery fire echoed across Kyiv as Russian forces renewed their offensive. https://t.co/2i2h1FmDkP https://t.co/lpGj4bg5fc

At least three people were killed in a Russian missile strike on a maternity hospital in Mariupol, Ukrainian officials said. People are cutting down trees for fuel and digging mass graves in the city, which has been encircled by Russian troops. https://t.co/pKGvJMBsmB https://t.co/GRm0l3ZFcT
President Biden is betting that Americans are willing to endure the financial pain that comes from waging an economic war with Russia. https://t.co/awddNyeszU

The Russian authorities started the process of banning Instagram in the country. They also opened a criminal case against Meta, Instagram’s parent company, asking a court to declare it an “extremist organization.”
Follow our updates on Ukraine. https://t.co/J8tpNnfXv6

Kyrylo Lysov, 22, and his girlfriend Yelyzaveta Sokolova, 20, shared a last moment together at the train station in Lviv. As refugees flee Ukraine, men between the ages of 18 and 60 are forbidden to leave, and many, like Lysov, are staying to fight. https://t.co/y2w72QEivB https://t.co/rLnVxINwoi

At least two million Ukrainians have fled Russia’s invasion. Amid sanctions and a clampdown on dissent, Russians, too, have been pouring out of their country in recent weeks.
But a Russian exodus to the U.S. was already well underway before the war. https://t.co/Rpwqt7LgNs https://t.co/hJlghX8QvD

The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol ran into a familiar roadblock on Thursday as Michael Flynn invoked his right against self-incrimination rather than answer questions about the events that led to a mob assault on Congress. https://t.co/ccpmQDNXtX

Ukraine accused President Vladimir Putin of ordering “the preparation of a terrorist attack” at the defunct Chernobyl nuclear plant, claiming Russian saboteurs had entered the facility posing as electrical repair workers. https://t.co/3jKqqeUS94
